item.title: West Virginia has a higher density of churches than Pennsylvania
item.description: Although Pennsylvania has nearly twice the land area of West Virginia, their number of churches is almost the same, according to Census and U.S. Geological Survey data. Oddly enough, the land area values come from the Census while the number of churches comes from the Geological Survey’s domestic names database, https://www.usgs.gov/core-science-systems/ngp/board-on-geographic-names/domestic-names. I started taking a look at the database Friday (Dec. 27, 2019) and decided to see if the data confirmed my personal experience that West Virginia seemed to have more churches per square mile than Pennsylvania or pretty much any other place I’d ever lived.

item.title: We have a lot of Guts
item.description: It’s been some time since I posted anything, so when I stumbled across this today, I thought it was worth a mention. Perusing the U.S. Geological Survey’s database of domestic names, I discovered the types of named features is a “Gut.” We have 3,497 of them. What are they? It took some digging, but I found this 1987 data user’s guide that provides this definition: “relatively small coastal waterway connecting larger bodies of water or other waterways (creek, inlet, slough).
